Palm Springs Air Museum.name: Palm Springs Air Museum
reviews:
This is an exceptional museum of aviation history capturing roughly the period of WWII through Vietnam.

The displays are VERY well laid out and the descriptions from signage and videos is amazing.

The condition of the "restored" aircraft and other items is a great testimony to the skill and dedication of the many hands that are involved in bringing these great creatures back to life.

Particularly poignant for me was the POW bracelet display and the associated wall of pictures of American heroes by their capture date. Too many faces I recognized.....and the memories that brought back.

I look forward to returning -- there is simply too much to properly absorb in one visit.

Very well done --- thank you all!
Show less

The PS Air Museum covers mostly military aircraft from WW 2 through today. There are also some civilian aircraft to augment the collection. There are fully restored aircraft (many airworthy), displays of models, uniforms, art, weapons, stories, dioramas, etc. There are plenty of docents there to answer questions, and there is a little café to get a snack. The museum is housed in a series of aircraft hangars that are open to the outside weather permitting. A very impressive air museum well worth a visit.
Show less

We went to the museum thinking it would be a short visit. There was so much to see and even touch we spent a half day! There are planes and jets from WW1 through current day. There is a small fee, but it is worth the money. You can even take a ride on a P-51 plane (much more expensive). Often there are events that you can attend. There are retired people associated with or retired from the military that help guide you or answer questions. It may be emotional if you have had a relative or have been in the military.
Show less

Aviators and history buffs alike will find plenty to see and learn in this collection. The aircraft are oriented chronologically by war experience and permit up and close inspection. Don’t miss the upstairs library, veteran interview recordings, and an opportunity to fly computer simulations. If you like talking aviation, military or otherwise, you’ll enjoy spending time with the old heads upstairs.
Show less
Recommended as an interesting day out

I had expected to see a lot of aircraft but they had put so much more into making this an interesting and worthwhile experience. There were hands on areas and a children’s section plus details and photos of the people that flew in these planes and also what happened to them. We spent most of the day there and had lunch in the little cafeteria this is a must visit in Palm Springs
Show less
So much to see. So much history to learn. They have veterans on hand to answer questions making the experience extra special. You must visit this museum.
Wonderful history of U.S. Military Aviation. Great tour by very knowledgeable guides. Spent a couple of hours there and will definitely go back for another tour.

The museum opened in 1996 and I think my husband and I came a year or two after that. It has grown a lot.
They have plenty of free parking and planes outside to view before entering the museum.
You check in at the Visitors Center, and go inside the gift shop. The admission fee is very reasonable, $17 for adults.
You are directed to Visitor Services where they tell you about the facility and give you a map. I also picked up a menu for the Freedom Fighters Cafe, but they were closed today, Thursday 2/15. They are having their Annual Gala tomorrow in the evening. It is a big fund raiser event for the museum, which is not funded by the government.
The menu looked good, hot dogs, hamburgers, sandwiches, salads, etc. All at reasonable prices. I would like to have lunch there, next time we go.
They have volunteers and docents (men who served in the military) that talk about the planes and exhibits and answer all your questions.
We arrived in the afternoon and stayed 2 1/2 hours. You really need more time to see everything. They are open from 10 am to 5 pm. Next time I want to spend 4-5 hours there and have lunch.
They have planes from WWII and jets. They also have a B-17 bomber open for a tour. My husband took the tour and said it was FANTASTIC! I am not a fan of close quarters so I didn't go inside.
There are plenty of exhibits to see and videos to watch. There is a section dedicated to women pilots and those who worked in the factories. They also have a F-16 flight simulator, that would be fun to do.
The hangars are all air conditioned which is nice.
The museum is a learning experience for both young and old. I don't remember being taught all this history in school.
On our way out, we stopped at the gift shop and bought a few things. A T-shirt and magnets.
All the proceeds from the gift shop and donations help keep the museum running to Preserve, Educate and Honor.
Yes, I did take some wording from their brochure to make sure what I write is correct.
I would HIGHLY recommend this attraction when in the Palm Springs area. Can't wait to come back!
Show less

The quality and quantity of aircraft and displays and general wartime information is world class. Although limited to the US during past conflicts, the aircraft on display are varied and in absolutely outstanding condition. The museum itself is spread through 4 connected, well maintained hangars. Around the inside perimeter of the hangars is enough military information to entertain both casual and serious historians for many hours. They also have a very large and dedicated group of veteran volunteers willing to add to the experience.
Show less
If you love history and planes, this is for you!

An intriguing visit to the Air Museum in Palm Springs as volunteers bring alive the history having lived through the times the planes were used. If it wasn't for the volunteers it would just be another airplane museum, but these passionate people share history that brings history alive. Give at least 4 hours to see everything. Definitely worth the time.
Show less

We had a lovely time here with the grandchildren. The museum has few barriers, allowing close interaction with the exhibits. There are planes you can climb in and sit at the controls - which went down really well with the children.

There is a good range of aircraft here, including many of WW2 vintage and some fast jets.

We had lunch in the cafe - also good, with a variety of basic food at reasonable prices.

Highly recommended - this museum should be able to keep anyone amused for a little while, even those with little interest in aviation.
Show less

This a great place to visit. A lot of planes and displays to see. Very well maintained. Planes and displays from WWII, Korea, Vietnam and Iraq and Afghanistan. Reasonable admission. Recommend this when in Palm Springs.
Up close and personal with the planes and airmen.

This is a wonderful museum, staffed by very friendly and informative aviation masters eager to answer your questions. We were able to actually stand underneath the open doors of a WWII bomber bay to see and learn how all the different sizes of bombs were loaded. To realize that these bomber crews were only 18-20 years old was both jaw-dropping and upsetting at the same time. Would highly recommend this as a 'do not miss' attraction in Palm Springs.
Show less

Love this museum. The aircraft are well maintained and they were even washing them during our visit. The docents are knowledgable and very nice. The exhibits are very interesting. I loved the decent guided tour of the B-17G aircraft. It looks so large on the outside, but the space for the crew is so limited. Amazing.
Show less

The other day I was touring the Palm Springs Art Museum and I see a lumbering WWII era C-47 overhead... it came from this museum, and they offer rides on it! The rest of the museum - so impressive. First time I ever went through the interior of the B-17 Flying Fortress. Hangers full of planes and parked outside also, civilian and military. Interesting exhibits throughout - videos, displays, models, artwork, educational things, exhibits honoring our military services. I spent a couple hours there and could have spent more I became so engrossed in everything. And I never took the airplane ride, although it was out flying while I was there, and then landed next door and taxied right into the museum court. A great experience, highly recommended. Um, the negative... its not exactly cheap - I think it takes a lot to keep all these machines in good shape; my Adult admission was $17.00. Still, unique and super high quality experience that you don't come across very often.
Show less
A fascinating place for all ages

Well worth the admission fee, which supports a magnificent collection of planes and artifact displays from WWII on. You don’t have to be an Air Force vet, like my husband, to enjoy a visit here. There are volunteers and ‘docents’ throughout the exhibits, many of whom are vets that had personal experiences with the planes on display and are happy to talk with or answer questions. In addition to the fixed displays, working planes are on the tarmac outside and some offer rides for the adventuresome.
Show less
Allow plenty of time for this one!
What a fabulous museum and a real tribute to those who have served. Be sure to allow time for the History channel movie, and the simulated air raids.
A Must See in Palm Springs

This air (and naval) museum is one of the best I've visited. The thing that stands out is that the majority of these aircraft actually are flight capable. We visit the Coachella Valley for a couple months per year and always take our visitors and guests to the air museum. It provides an excellent overview of history of WW11, the Korean and many of the other world conflicts since. For a vintage aircraft enthusiast, the photos won't end! The helpful volunteers are full of stories as many were directly involved with these airplanes. Watch for special weekend events which feature knowledgable speakers and often aircraft flight demonstrations celebrating specific world conflict events. The Canada Tribute Day is always well attended by snowbirds. There is also a small cafe to grab a snack and soda.
Show less
If you love Air Force, Naval Aviation, models of aircraft carriers, historical documentaries this is the place to go. Could have spent an entire day there.
There is lots of interesting things to see there if you are interested in our military history. Be sure to visit the library before you leave. There a lots of people there to explain things.

A very interesting museum seeing vintage airplanes from world war two and the Vietnam war. Interesting looking at the history of World War II in the Pacific and some from Vietnam war. Oh so interesting and looking at all of the conflicts that the US has been involved with countries around the world
Show less
Looking for something to do in Palm Springs? Check out the Palm Springs Air Museum!

This educational, volunteer-run organization is a terrific place to go and see aircraft dating back to WWII and up to Vietnam. Great historical displays in several hangars with music piped in to match the time periods. A gift shop and small cafe are also on site.

We've been there in the past with our grandchildren and they enjoyed it very much!
Show less

Great collection of WW2 and Vietnam era aircraft. The volunteers are extremely knowledgeable and eager to share their knowledge. You can see an example of the F-104 that Chuck Yeager flew, without permission and crashed, as depicted at the end of the movie The Right Stuff. Be sure to tour the B17 Bomber, definitely the highlight of the tour.
Show less

Many planes from WWII, Korean War and Vietnam!! Plus many interest exhibits, including a shadowbox description on the attack on Pearl Harbor, models of many war ships (destroyers, battleships, etc). The B-17 is one of the stars of the show!!

There are four hangers of planes and exhibits, plus more planes outside. It is across from the Palm Springs Airport and has access to the airport for taxi ways and the runway when they are operating the planes.

A nice touch are the docents who are veterans of the wars and always willing to chat!
Show less
Airplane Buffs will be in Heaven

Airplanes from World War II, the Korean War and Vietnam are on display in four large hangars. There is a B-17 that can be toured for an added $5 fee that my husband enjoyed. Around the sides are other displays, some with videos. There are many volunteers to give you information as you visit each section.
Show less

to fully explore this great museum. This place has some of the best explanations of WW2 battles I've seen - and we've been to dozens of Air Museums around the world. Gorgeous painted murals cover the walls, and beautiful tributes to the Tuskegee Airman, Gulf War and Vietnam vets as well as dozens of beautifully restored planes fill the halls. If you are a Vet, know a Vet or have any interest in war history, you will love this gem.
Show less

Ended up staying most of the day. There is something for everyone here with aircraft from WWII thru Desert Storm on exhibit. I had a personal interest in the B-17 because my uncle was KIA after a bombing raid over Berlin in 1944. He was the co-pilot. For a small additional fee you can actually get inside the B-17 which I did. It was an overwhelming, once in a lifetime (for me, probably) experience. The Docents here are priceless. There are several films played throughout the day in the theatre, and there is a research library on the second floor. I got some leads from the Librarian that might help me learn even more about my uncle. I'm so glad I went and I am so grateful to the people who have the foresight and ability to preserve these aircraft and the heroic stories of the Patriots who made up their crews. Visit this air museum. You won't regret it. A wonderful learning experience for the kids too.

We went to the Palm Springs Air Museum with our grand kids to have a great and informative day. Bummer, we were so done disappointed that we will write reviews to any social media’s available. Kids are definitely not welcome there. They could not seat on any plane, and were told that there were too little to understand. Since when it is an adult museum? We build that visit for weeks to be rebuffed by people who have no customer service or understanding how you can ruin little kids day. I definitely DO NOT recommend that place to visit.
Totally UNACCEPTABLE
Their advertising should let people know that kids are not welcome there

Staff by veterans who know their stuff. There's lots to see covering most of the planes that flew in WWII as well as an old fire truck, 2 vintage cars. It borders on the PS airport so you can watch the planes fly in and out. I think there was only one plane that you could actually climb in the cockpit.

This museum is outstanding. Not just for their collection of airbirds but for models of ships, info about famous pilots. We thoroughly enjoy the Korea and Vietnam hangar. There were many doecents who could answer questions.
We have visited a lot of air museums and Palm Springs Air Museum is as good as it gets. It’s staff is knowledgeable but they don’t over power you. Everything is squeaky clean and maintained.

Largest air museum after Evergreen (OR). War themed, some very rare flying exhibits, many good tutorial booths, very fair entry price, dozens of docents, many ex-pilots. Takes a while to see it all--like 2 hours.

So much history at this museum. Airplanes are awesome. Worth a visit at any age. Not only do you get to go through airplane hangars full of planes, as a side benefit you can watch the planes at the Palm Springs Airport take off and land. The cost is $17.00 to enter. There is also a small restaurant. We had lunch there, and it was very good. Reasonably priced too.

One of the best air museums in the US I’ve been to many this is worth a stop If your hungry there’s a place to eat if you’re thirsty there’s a place to drink if you want air-conditioning in the hot summer they have at the airplanes they have there are some of the finest examples of airplanes are seen in the world not to mention almost all of their airplanes must be maintained in flyable condition you will not find that with the aircraft and other museums though there are impeccable condition they do not fly

We were visiting Palm Springs with a group of 17 (ages 10 to 73) so decided to check out the Air Museum. Everyone loved it! The kids loved the flight simulators and the grandparents liked talking to the staff about the history of the planes. Highly recommend.

Went there with our Son & Daughter-in-law and Granddaughter had a great day felt very informed. Would love to go back again 😎😎
This museum has the broadest collection of WWII and Vietnam fighter aircraft anywhere. The contrast between the 1940's and late 60's aircraft is amazing. Lot's of great stories. Wonderful volunteers.

We went to look at the planes and tour the B-17; loved them, but the stories, memorabilia and many volunteers were the highlight. As a veteran, I appreciated the meticulous care, detail and research so obvious in their displays. The Pearl Harbor attack diorama was exceptional.

My father was visiting for a month and he is a veteran of WW ll. He is now 94 years old and thoroughly enjoyed the displays spanning the WW ll Pacific and European theaters, along with Korea and Vietnam. Most of the aircraft are still flyable and pass over my home on special occasions.

$15 senior rate. 49 Vintage aircraft and a B-17 bomber open for interior touring. Great docents that help you understand the history and use of each plane. A B-25 Mitchell bomber like used on the Doolittle raid. Also a BRITISH Spitfire & 3 Migs. WWII, Korean, & Vietnam planes, with displays everywhere and pictures of Write Brothers flights, Tuskegee Red Tails and women aviators

It was nice to see all those planes in perfect condition and to be able to seat in the copkit of a real war plane!
The only time I have been this close to planes is when I FLY IN THEM!! haha. Seriously super duper cool.

Lots of lovingly and carefully restored aircraft. Vast majority of them are in one of three large hanger areas each for a different war time - WWI, WWII and VietNam. Museum also has information on particular pilots, details about the wars, uniforms, medals, etc. Shades of Maverick and TopGun, I especially liked the film about a dogfight during the VietNam war. There are a number of docents eager to share their experiences and knowledge. Small cafe in the rear food and drink. Discounts for military and AAA as well as some occasional other coupons.

My husband and I enjoyed our visit here! Get a great history lesson across the many decades and wars. I also enjoyed watching the planes take off and land next door. Beautiful views of the mountains too!
Really great even if this is not something that in your typical interest!

My husband has been telling me this is the best museum he has ever gone to for the last several years. I finally went, and although I may not go that far, I really enjoyed it (my interests generally run more toward art, food, design, fashion, etc). The stories that are told are incredible and there is so much to see. We were there for several hours, but I think it would probably take several visits to see everything and do it justice.

Would recommend this amazing museum collection for all ages. A definite must for tourists to Palm Springs.

If you have ANY interest in aviation this is a must see museum, even if you aren't an aviation enthusiast it is worth the entry price. Lots of vintage WWII and other aircraft, and there is always veteran fliers there to relate their experiences of flying the aircraft and tell you the history of them. I went there while waiting for my flight and didn't have to have the rental car back, so it's just a 5 minute drive to the other side of the airport. Great place for kids too. Highly recommend that you go to visit it, as a previous reviewer said you can spend hours there.

We visited this hidden jewel on the first Saturday of 2018 and listened to Lt. Col. Dean Hunter tell his story. He is a great story teller. He is also a docent at the museum on a regular basis. I encourage you to visit this wonderful jewel in Palm Springs. They have four hangars of aircraft and displays that are very well done. It is easy to spend a day there.

What a remarkable place. Hangers from WWII thru Vietnam are filled. There were a few Vets to answer questions & tell you about their experiences at Korea & Vietnam. The MIA/POW wall & Bracelets they've collected is worthwhile seeing. You can enjoy being a pilot & gunner upstairs too.

What a unique air museum where they actually fly the airplanes

A unique air museum where they actually fly the airplanes. A lot of atmosphere is added by the veterans working as guides in the museum. One of the best air museums I have ever been to. Our 2 year old kid loved the old fire truck though. And to add to this they are actually flying these amazing machines when we were there. Just wow. This is a must to visit when in the area.

A must see when in Palm Springs!

This museum is incredible not just because of the planes, exhibits, library, and flight simulator, but because of the amazing docents, many of whom are veterans. They add so much to the experience of this museum with their knowledge and personal history. They were so friendly and accessible, often walking up to us and beginning a conversation. We spoke at length with Jim, who was just amazing with his knowledge of aircraft carriers and warships.

Beyond the docents, the airplanes are fascinating. They are all parked on the ground (versus hanging from the ceiling) so you can touch them, look in the windows, and even climb into some.

This museum is well worth your time. It is interesting and highly educational.

Had a great time. So many photos, info, and memorabilia. Flight simulators, theater to view films, library, lots of planes to climb into and explore. Many Vets work there and are very knowledgeable.Cute gift shop.

Must see for history buffs and airplane buffs alike, and for those who want to teach their kids that freedom isn't free. We were hear over Christmas vacation, and they fired up and flew two of their vintage planes as a gift to their guests. Such a treat! I can't say enough about the volunteers here. All were so knowledgeable, friendly and gracious. A great group of folks!

This is now my favorite air museum

This is now my favorite air museum because you can get close and touch the aircraft and even climb through the B17. There are also many volunteers who have great stories and facts that make the place special. Since we had a few hours until our flight departed out of PSP, my wife and I spent just over 2 hours there, and we are so glad we did so. I have been to air museums in Europe, Wash DC, Virginia, McMinnville, +; and this one deserves a visit.

The Palm Springs Air Museum is located next to the Palm Springs Airport. It has an excellent collection of vintage air craft from the Second, Korean and Vietnam Wars. It is housed in converted hangers which gives you an appreciation of how these aircrafts helped to fight these conflicts. Retired veterans are more than happy to offer insight into the life and times of air men during these difficult times.

We have been to both sites of the Air & Space Museum numerous times and found this a unique and enjoyable experience. Staffed entirely by very knowledgeable volunteers and offering hands-on opportunities, it was fun and educational.
Very nice museum. large variety of planes and displays. Staffed by members very enthusiastic about their museum. Stopped to listen to their stories of service to the United States.

Great air museum, especially if you are interested in military air history. There is some general aviation history, as well, including a nice wall dedicated to women in aviation. Kind and helpful docents everywhere ! Good sandwiches and burgers for great price in the cafe !

Fascinating museum to visit, veteran pilots present each time. A lot of dedication and hours showing love of the history of flight went into this museum. I keep returning as I find something new to learn, or a new film or video to see each time. Fascinating!

The planes were wonderful, and our guide was so informative, we really enjoyed everything about this tour. Would definitely recommend to anyone who has any interest in planes or history.
Have a few hours to be able to see everything. Learned a lot, Lots of very interesting stories. Many people to help you around and to ask questions to. Worth going to see.
Wow, this is a new must stop for my visitors to the Desert

Spent 2 hours with my brother there after we met a docent at breakfast. Fascinating salute to the Best Generation, and to all those who have served,so that we may live in Peace. I immediately became a member.

Our family really enjoyed the displays, history, the Warbird’s and other aircraft at this museum. The docents were extremely friendly and knowledgeable. Go by and tour. Your admission fee and donations help them keep these birds flying!
Great place to study history and see some beautiful airplanes

We spent a couple of hours at the museum and still have one hangar we didn't get to. Beautifully kept planes, enthusiastic and caring docents. And, for $15, not a bad price for adults. There is also a cafe and gift shop. Take time to climb inside the B17 Flying Fortress and imagine what it was like for the crew!

This museum is just wonderful and gives adults and youngsters alike the opportunity to see aircraft up close and there are lots of exhibits and you can enter and explore all sorts of planes.
Excellent staff and volunteers, best opportunity to see US military aircraft. On certain days, open access cockpit tours, and some occasions flying aircraft take passengers.

We went there to see one of the planes our nephew flew for the Navy. We were told it his name would be left on it and wanted to take a picture. Well it was and we did. One of the guides took us to the plane and gave us some history on it, it's arrival and so forth. He was very knowledgeable and helpful. I thought I was just going to kill some time before I picked my sister up at the airport. But I brought my sister back with me and we enjoyed checking out the planes and many of the interesting displays. Very well done.

I grew up flying (instead of driving) to see my grandparents and family. My dad was a pilot and worked his entire life in general aviation. Having been around airplanes most of my life I like to see museums dedicated to aviation. The Palm Springs Air Museum is one of the best! A beautiful Staggerwing Beech had just landed and was on display, a fantastic restoration of this 1930's aircraft is just one of many fully operational historic planes you can see at the museum. We toured an airworthy B-17 (you can walk through) to get the experience of what it was like to be in the aircraft, what the crew did and how they did it. Most of the planes on display are airworthy (meaning they can still fly) with complete backstories of the planes and the people who flew them. The staff are very helpful and knowledgeable, eager to help you understand what your looking at. You don't need to be an aviation enthusiast to enjoy this museum. Allow yourself at least a couple of hours to fully experience, a must see if your in the area!

Staff were friendly and knowledgeable and exhibits were extensive and excellent. A must see for pilots or those interested in aviation.

This is a really cool military museum to visit, especially since the restorations are accomplished by dedicated veteran volunteers. The old planes look fantastic, and are backed up with detailed information kiosks and film. I especially liked the veteran volunteers there to answer questions. The B-17 can be toured for an additional $5. Easy to spend a couple of hours here and well worth it. Also cool to watch jets taking off at next door runway.

If you are interested in air planes this museum is a must. They have the largest collections of World War II flyable planes. They also have American history on the war and how the air power changed the outcome of the war.

We learned so much. A real enjoyable day. Learn about our history and those who fought for us all. Not just for military or WWII history buffs.

We went to the air museum thinking there would be a few planes. Not so!! There were four hangers packed with planes! Great place to learn about past wars and how planes helped and changed through the wars. The docents are very knowledgeable and are everywhere! They even have a list of POWs where we found my great uncles name. All ages would enjoy this trip.

My son (8 y) loved it here. Learned a lot and had a wonderfully interactive experience. The B17 was a highlight.
Great escape to beat the heat

The airplanes and helicopters on display were great to see. Loved the historical displays and technical information they gave about each machine. The docents were a lot of retired military with great stories.
Terrific-must go if you have Rug Rats

very well done air museum, lots of old timers manning the place as voluteers-well done. we were fortunate to see one of the planes used in the pacific in wwII start its engines and then to our astonishment, it taxied to the runway and sure enough it took off-a terrific sight

Fascinating collection of historial artifacts that bring personal experiences alive

We were pleasantly surprised at the breadth and depth of the collection. In addition to the aircraft that served in WWII, Korean War and Vietnam War, there are dozens of models of airplanes and war ships, uniforms, personal letters, photographs, and other memorabilia. There is a strong educational component, with recorded videos in various areas, an interactive children's area, lecture room, and special exhibits honoring women in service, the Tuskegee Airmen, US Presidents in service, to name a few,
Staff of volunteer docents are mostly war veterans that are ready and willing to share their experiences to enrich a visitor's appreciation of the real action that took place -- really makes history come alive!
We saw so much in 2 hours, but there is so much more to see. We will definitely return another time!

I thought this museum was great. I am not generally interested in airplanes, but anybody who went through WWll or if your parents told your stories, or if you used to watch war movies, this is really an interesting way to spend a couple of hours. The best part is that it has so many volunteers working there, many of them war vets, that you can practically get your own guided tour, just keep asking questions. You can climb inside planes and imagine what it was like for the young men who actually had to fly in them. The whole thing became a fascinating history lesson. I highly recommend it.

A Great Air Museum at Palm Springs Airport

I love air museums, and this is among the best I've visited. It focuses on military aircraft from WW2, Korea and Vietnam, impressively displayed in three era-specific hangars on spacious grounds.
The highlight: the perfectly preserved B-17 you can tour with a docent for a small extra charge. Well, well worth it, especially in view of how rare they have become. Most planes are in flyable condition. The entire facility is lovingly spotless and possesses a strong historical and patriotic vibe.
Wonderful for all ages and plenty of parking at its convenient location at Palm Springs airport.

I did an event at the museum and was offered a free and unsupervised tour. The aircraft they have are awesome. It's a great way to spend the day, especially when the weather is super hot. You can visit this ir conditioned museum and see some very cool stuff!

Enjoy the air museums and all the history they have,. The guides were excellent and gave us a lot of information. Would go back again

First of all, I am not a big enthusiast of museums. To me, museums are full of dust, old items and memories. However, after passing by this museum for the past 20 years and not going in, I made an effort to see it this year. I was more than just pleasantly surprised at how clean and well-lit all the displays were and how much work has gone in to make this a museum of history of our military aviation and included some film and hands-on demonstrations. It is divided into segments that include WW2, Korean War, Vietnam and the cold war. There is a wonderful library with catalogues of information and yearly chronicle of events. There is also a flight simulator than can be operated with the supervision of an instructor. I thoroughly enjoyed talking to all the volunteers in the different locations and they were very knowledgeable and eager to answer questions or add to the explanations of the displays. Many of the aircraft have small replica models that show cut-away portions of the fuselage and other operating parts of war planes. Seeing what is underneath the skin of the airplane was very interesting. Many of these aircraft are flown even today. It is well worth spending at least three hours in this museum, longer if you really want to absorb our aviation progress for the last 75 years.

I was so surprised by this museum. It was well worth the visit. Our history is so fascinating from the aviators perspective. It is so interesting to see all the different kinds of jets and planes up close. Even on a couple of them you can go inside. The people who are there to guide you thru the museum are so helpful and knowledgeable. I would not miss this museum.

I did not expect to find a museum of this quality in Palm Springs. First, the facility is first class; large modern hangers, The quality and diversity of the planes on exhibit is amazing. A number of them are actually operational. There are many great examples of aircraft from the 2nd world war, Korea and Vietnam conflicts so it is difficult to pick out any favorites but I was particularly impressed with the B-17 and B-25 bombers. For an additional $5 you can tour through the B-17. The guides that are located through out the facility are very helpful and knowledgeable. This air museum is truly where history comes alive. The museum is huge over 89,000 square feet. There are over 49 vintage aircraft From WWII through Korea and Vietnam. PSAM is a great place for history or aviation buffs and a wonderful museum for visitors of all types. We were lucky to be able to visit on Veteran's Day as the museum had live fly-bys as well as B-25 and Stearman biplane rides. The displays are very well maintained as many of the planes are in flyable condition and you can get "up close and personal" with virtually all of them. The docents are friendly, helpful and a great source of information. It's well worth it to spend the day there, as reading all of the information displays, watching the many video presentations, and admiring the planes and the courage and dedication of the men and women that flew them will take some time. Better yet, come back a second or third time to catch all the things you missed before!

Palm Springs Air Museum Is Great Fun And Worth The Time

At first glance I had no idea how big this museum was. Wow! It has wartime aircraft in four big air conditioned hangers and even more outside on the tarmac. The displays are very well done with explanations of all aircraft on display. I was lucky enough to meet a docent, David Sawyer, who was extremely knowledgeable and was able to give me all kinds of tidbits about the planes and their history in wartime. Make sure to make enough time to spend several hours. There's lots to see.

A fine collection of old (and some not so old) warbirds. The volunteers are well informed, informative, and enjoyable characters who help make the exhibits enjoyable, including some of the histories of the aircraft types on display. The flight simulators are fun, even though we non-pilots seemed to have a tendency to crash. Strongly recommended for anyone who has an interest in military aviation.

We spent hours at the Air Museum and it was awesome. So many interesting stories, items and the staff was well-trained and could answer any questions. So many interesting aircraft and a well-stocked library you could spend an entire day here.

It was nice to get up close and see some of the "warbirds" on display here. Knowledgeable docents. Look for their discounted admission coupon in the local guide. Allow at least 90 minutes for your visit; more if you want to try the computer flight simulations.

Best air museum I have ever experienced. Focused mostly on WW II through Vietnam era's. The volunteers that help run the museum are very knowledgeable and friendly, which helps make the visit even more special. We worth a 1-2 hour visit.

If you love military aircraft, this is the place for you.

Went late afternoon about 2 hrs before closing on a Sunday. We had the place pretty much to ourselves. Spouse took the private tour of a B-17 bomber and loved it. He was able to go inside the plane and lol around.

We spent so much time looking at the planes that we ran out of time to go upstairs to try the simulators so we must come back.

There is a building that has aircraft from the Korean and Vietnam wars that can only be entered from the outside so don't forget to visit that room.
